title: Release Notes for Safari Technology Preview 171

last_post.content:
Safari Technology Preview 171 adds:
- `@font-face { src: tech() }` and `@supports font-tech()`
- `@font-face` `size-adjust`
- additional language support for list counters: 29 Ethiopic, 3 Korean, and 4 Chinese styles
- renaming `leading-trim` to `text-box-trim`and `text-edge` to `text-box-edge`
- the new `<search>` element in HTML
- `AbortSignal.any()`
- `ServiceWorkerRegistration.getNotifications()`
- `getDisplayMedia` video track clone resizing

Plus a lot more… https://webkit.org/blog/14200/release-notes-for-safari-technology-preview-171/

title:
Die Wissenschaftlerinnen on Instagram: "🚀Jun.-Prof. Dr. @m_k_schumacher ist Juniorprofessorin für Digital Humanities an der Universität Regensburg (@dhregensburg). 

📚Sie forscht und lehrt unter anderem in den Bereichen Narratologie und digitale Gender Studies und hat ein besonderes Faible für komplexe Analysen großer Datenmengen. Im Projekt m*w erforscht sie literarische Darstellungen von Gender, um zu erfahren, welche Stereotype es gibt und wie diese aufgebrochen werden. 

🔍In der Kooperation mit WIM beteiligt sie sich an der Auswertung von Social Media Daten im Hinblick auf vorherrschende Narrative, die die mediale Darstellung von Wissenschaftlerinnen prägen.

#forschung #wissenschaft #digitalhumanities #forschungbaby"

last_post.content: It's #DayofDH and news about a brand new cooperation between us and Judith Ackermann from the FH Potsdam just got published. In an interdisciplinary approach we will analyze narratives about female scientists and humanists. We do so in a data-driven study on social media postings. Very much looking forward to it! Find more information about what #DigitalHumanities has got to do with it here: https://www.instagram.com/p/Cs6Krs0oQyR/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link&igshid=MzRlODBiNWFlZA==

title: GitHub - isawnyu/pleiades_wayback: A script to help ensure all Pleiades place pages get a snapshot at archive.org after they've been changed.

last_post.content:
The #PleiadesGazetteer @internetarchive bot usually takes a few hours to run since I've built in generous crawl delays and generously increasing retry delays when 5xx errors are encountered.

I use requests.sessions with customized settings (including "Retry" from urllib3.util.retry) and some try/except behaviors in loops paired with the good old python "sleep" function to make it all happen. I'm not in a hurry; I'd rather the script not fail too often.

https://github.com/isawnyu/pleiades_wayback

#DayOfDH2023

title: Karin Dalziel (@nirak@hcommons.social)

last_post.content:
It's been 6 months (where did that time go?) since I posted about using tasks for #Obsidian and it is going great. I 've tried so many productivity systems and this is the one that has stuck the best.

The real advantage is I take most of my notes in the Daily Note, and as to do's come up, I just add them inline. So when I am reminded about a task totally unrelated to the meeting I am in (common) I can just add my todo inline and continue with the meeting.

title: Karin Dalziel (@nirak@hcommons.social)

last_post.content:
Oh, hey, #DayofDH2023, and the first Day of DH I’ll have spent on this network rather than that other one. I'm in the midst of drafting my keynote for #ReclaimOpen, which is all about the failed sociality of social networks, and how it undermined the potential for sociality elsewhere online. So it's appropriate to find myself here, on an instance of a distributed network on which we're hoping to build new kinds of connection and engagement.

Not at all incidentally, given @nirak's post linked below, I'm drafting that talk in #Obsidian, and pushing it from there to #GitHub, where it's running in #reveal.js. (Drafting the talk is also a task I'm tracking in #Obsidian. I am :100: a true believer.)

Next on today's agenda is an online workshop with the #HumanitiesCommons team. And then more writing.

https://hcommons.social/@nirak/110463785532000788

title: Upcoming Webinars - FromThePage Blog

last_post.content:
A quick distraction on #dayofdh2023 to check the sign up lists our next two webinars. (We run one per month on #crowdsourcing and have started another on AI in libraries as we explore #ChatGPT etc.)

Tomorrow's webinar on the soft skills required to start and run crowdsourcing projects has 42 people signed up, which is a lot higher than usual.

The June 22/23 webinar on prompt writing for ChatGPT will be run in two sections, so that we can include more participants from outside North America. Current sign-ups for that are Atlantic 117; Pacific 25.

We've been really pleased with the experience of running webinars, especially when we interview other practitioners. It's a nice way to share ideas without needing to travel to a conference, and the informal formats seem to work well.

(If you're interested, our sign-up form is at https://content.fromthepage.com/webinars/ )

title: Open, Digital, Collaborative Project Preservation in the Humanities | Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI)

last_post.content:
Talks aren't posted yet as of when I'm writing this, but I did submit one for https://dhsi.org/open-digital-collab-2023/ about data as the basis for sustainability.

I assert that we need to work at the right level of abstraction that lets us capture the human intent. Domain specific languages (DSLs) are one way to represent intent as data interpreted by an engine.

In today's work with Surface, HTML and CSS are too low-level. That's why we have React/Vue/Surface to capture the UX intent.

#DayOfDH2023 #DayOfDH
